text: hi everyone snipthanysniptano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new church's
album screen violence this is the fourth
full-length lp from elektro and synth
pop trio churches kicking off this
latest decade with a bit of an artistic
bounce back that has a lot of fans
excited truth be told i have not been a
huge church's fan up until this point
while their debut brought a lot of
potential and serious highlights to the
table the creativity and novelty behind
their sound seemed to diminish as they
dropped more projects with 2018's love
is dead being their weakest showing yet
but screen violence sees the trio
bringing it back to basics a little bit
the huge dramatic and anthemic synth pop
tunes are back but maybe this time with
more of a cinematic presentation the
music on this one is sounding more
appropriate for the soundtrack to a
coming-of-age film as opposed to you
know a mall dressing room
speaker there's even a slight rock edge
to some of the heavier hooks on this
project too the results of which may be
a bit more melodramatic and cloying but
at least this lp challenges you to feel
something which i just didn't really get
that from love is dead the track list
here offers the most highlights the band
has brought to the table in a while like
asking for a friend which is a stunning
opener the fact that lauren mayberry's
voice still sounds so emotive and
distinct wrapped up in all these synths
and effects is a testament to her
singing and delivery the growing layers
of beats bass and lead melodies in the
first half are pulled off masterfully
and the track only gets better as we
transition into full-on dance grooves
from then on there violent delights was
also a highlight to my ears righteous
tune and the crisp break beat propelling
all of it was a refreshing change of
pace then how not to drown with the
great robert smith is undoubtedly a
massive moment in the band's catalog too
and even before robert enters the
picture it's a great track the drum beat
is huge the pianos are so lush and the
chord progression is bittersweet there's
also something so incredibly urgent
about lauren's singing on this cut too
it kind of reminds me of some classic
cranberry singles from back in the day
smith's contribution to the track is of
course fantastic his voice mixes so well
with lauren's sure the song does get
needlessly spacey and drags out a bit
too much around the bridge but uh it's
still an incredible track and speaking
of the cure final girl kind of sounds
like something the band would have
recorded back in the day at least in
terms of the song's goth rock adjacent
intro after that it more or less sounds
like your typical church's song but i do
appreciate the trio bringing a bit more
nuance instrumentally and vocally to
this one the very bright and shimmering
guitars on the back end of the track are
a great touch too so look there are some
great single and standout tracks on this
lp i won't deny that in fact i expected
it but as far as the overall listening
experience there's not a whole lot that
this record brings to the table with it
just being your standard 10 track affair
with nearly every song trying to
culminate as much hit potential as
possible because of that it sort of ends
up being a one-dimensional listening
experience even with the closing track
attempting a stripped back number
because across this lp there are so many
attempts at a reverb drenched high gloss
synth pop bop most of which are
scratching a similar emotional itch in
doing so to varying degrees of success
like for example the choruses on he said
she said are incredible some of the
biggest on the entire lp but it would be
an omission not to acknowledge how much
the verses drag plus the dialogue in the
lyrics portrayed is a bit too reductive
even if it is reflective of unfair
expectations lauren may feel are being
projected onto her or maybe women in
general then the song california it's
almost as if this one is blissfully
unaware of how overdone this angle is
that uh we've heard such great things
it's an amazing place we went there and
then found out it's actually awful
did we not just have that wolf alice
album that uh was essentially you know
getting to the heart of the same issue
with that being said i like the sound of
this record a lot more but uh churches
is far from an untapped narrative here
the kill your idols commentary of good
girls is a lot more timely and i think
necessary but mayberry does arrive to a
few somewhat awkward word choices flow
choices melodic choices trying to fit in
every single thing she wants to say in
her lyrics so again while there are
quality tracks on this lpi can easily
pull out and highlight that still
doesn't change that the record overall
is a bit too uniform and also formulaic
with even some tracks lacking
imagination on the lyrical and the
instrumental side feeling a strong five
to a light six on this one tran position
have you given this album a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best you're the
best what should i review next hit the
like if you like please subscribe and
please don't cry hit the bell as well
over here next to my head it's another
video you can check out hit that up or
the link to subscribe to the channel
anthonyfantano
churches
forever
